questions.question: What is an Anti-Corruption Layer (ACL)?

options.text: A security layer for preventing data breaches
A protective barrier between your clean domain model and external systems with poor or incompatible models
An encryption layer for sensitive data
A validation layer for user input

questions.explanation: An Anti-Corruption Layer (ACL) is a protective barrier between your clean domain model and external systems with poor or incompatible models. It acts as a translator, preventing 'corruption' of your domain's ubiquitous language.

questions.question: What happens without an ACL when integrating with a legacy system?

options.text: Performance improves due to direct access
Legacy model terminology and data formats leak into your domain code

questions.explanation: Without an ACL, legacy model terminology (like 'CUST_ID', 'ACCT_STATUS') and data formats (like 'MM/DD/YYYY') leak into your domain code, forcing your domain logic to deal with awkward legacy transformations everywhere.

questions.question: An ACL translates external models into your domain's ubiquitous language before they reach your domain layer.
questions.explanation: The ACL translates external concepts into your domain language. For example, it converts 'ACCT_STATUS: A' into 'AccountStatus.Active' and 'CUST_TYPE: I' into 'CustomerType.Individual'.

questions.question: Which design patterns are typically used to implement an ACL?
questions.explanation: ACLs are typically implemented using the Adapter pattern (to translate between interfaces) and Facade pattern (to simplify complex external systems). These patterns isolate your domain from external complexity.

questions.question: ACLs should translate data in both directions - from external to domain and from domain to external.
questions.explanation: ACLs handle bidirectional translation. When reading, they convert external models to domain objects. When writing, they convert domain objects back to the format expected by external systems.
